name: Leland's Description of Manchester (1542)
description: John Leland's Itinerary (1542) describes Manchester as 'the fairest, best builded, quickest, and most populous town in all Lancashire'. The first detailed written account — could inform a reconstruction map.
notes:
RESEARCH TARGET: Find any maps/reconstructions based on Leland's description.

Leland's Itinerary (1542) excerpt on Manchester:
'Manchester on the south side of the Irwell is the fairest, best builded,
quickest, and most populous town in all Lancashire.'

He describes:
- The bridge over the Irwell
- The Collegiate Church
- The streets and buildings
- The cloth market / textile trade
- Salford on the other side of the river

Leland's text is in 'The Itinerary of John Leland' (edited by Lucy Toulmin Smith, 1907-10).
Available at Internet Archive.

Possible reconstruction sources:
- Any scholarly attempt to map Leland's Manchester
- Tudor town reconstruction drawings
- Compare with 1650 plan (source 25) — only 108 years later

Manchester in 1542: population maybe 2,000-3,000.
Textile trade well established — fustians, woollens.
Grammar School recently founded (1515).
